It might not be what you are used to, but try a Hare Hare Hare or an Edmundrsquos Folly.. Panda and Sons, Edinburgh Queen Street, EdinburghOpen Monday- Friday,pm-late and Saturday-Sunday, pm- ate  www.pandaandsonsThis speakeasy-style bar, disguised as a barbershop, is accessed through a secret bookshelf door to add a sense of drama to your night out. The excitement continues with the cocktails: some change colour, some are served in a hat and some lsquosteamrsquo with dry ice. They arenrsquot cheap, but for the atmosphere they are more than worth it ndash plus the bar pays the living wage to all its staff.. The West House, DundeeThe Westhouse,  Westport, DundeeOpen every day until am www.thewesthouseThere is a relaxed, laidback atmosphere in the West House, but that doesnrsquot mean that they havenrsquot put extensive thought into their cocktail menu. They offer the classics with a twist as well as their own creations, and the range is very reasonably priced considering the qualityof spirits that they use.. Neurorsquos DumfriesNeurorsquos Bar, Restaurant and Spa, The Crichton, Bankend Road, DumfriesOpen Monday- Saturday, am-pm and Sunday, .pm-pm  www.neurosOne of the most sophisticated venues in Dumfries, Neurorsquos sits outside the town centre on the grand Chrichton Estate. Its impressive cocktail menu makes it well worth the trip ndash with the bartenders happy to go off-menuyour favourite isnrsquot on their list.. Meraki Stirling King Street, StirlingOpen Monday-Thursday, pm-am, Friday-Saturday pm-am and Sunday pm-am Popular with locals, Meraki is a reasonably small bar that gets busy quickly, so it might be best to book ahead. They have a range of classic cocktails for a very reasonable pound, but they also frequently introduce seasonal creations and special deals. And, asyou needed more reasons to visit, they offer complimentary popcorn.. Browns Glasgow George Square, GlasgowOpen Monday-Thursday, am-pm, Friday-Saturday am-am and Sunday am-pm  www.browns-restaurantsThe elegant Browns Bar, situated in a former Post Office building built  years ago, provides an ideal setting to enjoy a sophisticated cocktail: with a menu of signature, seasonal, spritz and sparkling ieties to choose from. And with George Square being the home of Glasgowrsquos Christmas markets and attractions, you are in the perfect place to get into the spirit.. Bar , Aberdeen Back Wynd, AberdeenOpen Monday- Thursday, am-am, Friday- Saturday, am-am and Sunday, :pm-am www.aberdeenThe cocktails in Bar  are pretty impressive, but its staff make it a cut above. They are friendly, knowledgeable and accommodating and will be happy to take requests for any cocktails that arenrsquot on the menu.. Jam Jar, Bridge of Allan Henderson Street, Bridge of Allan, StirlingOpen weekdays, pm- , and weekends pm-late www.jamjarcafeIt might not be the biggest venue on our list, but this cosy cafeacute bar has a huge cocktail menu that covers gin, rum, vodka, prosecco, bourbon, and tequila cocktails. But for those that arenrsquot drinking, the Jam Jar doesnrsquot treat you like an afterthought. Rather than throwing in a few token mocktails, they have an extensive and considered non-alcoholic menu that includes virgin versions of a Pina Colada, Mojito and Bellini.. The Tree House, AyrOpen Sunday-Thursday, am-am and Friday-Saturday, am-.am- Sandgate, Ayr  www.thetreehouse-ayrThis bright, stylishly venue isthemed around trees, with leaves dangling from the ceiling, plants adorning the windowsills and two large trees in the centre of the bar. The drinks are equally trendy, with the cocktails made to an impeccable standard and served with a smile.. The Devilrsquos Advocate, EdinburghOpen every day, pm-am Advocates Close, Edinburgh  www.devilsadvocateedinburghHidden up Advocatersquos Close in an old Victorian pump house, the Devilrsquos Advocate might not look like a traditional cocktail bar. But donrsquot let first impressions put you off: it is actually one of the most specialist cocktail venues in the city, with an imaginative list of geographically-themed drinks that offers an exciting alternative to more standard cocktails.

title: kevin-bridges-what-he-really-thinks-about-his-showbiz-contemporaries
story: But whatrsquos inside his expensively barbered head  When the riches of Croesus arrive at the doors of entertainers in Eddie Stobart-sized loadscommon sense iniably leaps out the window. Before you know it, the Columbian dancing dust has taken hold and the next thing you know theyrsquore filling in forms for the rehab clinic and scrubbing out toilets with Lindsay Lohan.Yes, Bridges has already been through his late-twenties existentialist period of drinking too much and wonderinghersquod had enough of comedy. And he has an ongoing issue with hecklers. . But hersquos not only gotten his act together hersquos filling even bigger halls for longer periods, the  nights at the SSE Hydro in October being a case in point. So whatrsquos going right  What keeps him grounded, away from the opportunistic platinum blondes and the urge to flash the Platinum Amex  What keeps him away from the Chiltern Firehouse, in Londons Marylebone, and having selfies taken with Nick Grimshaw and Caroline Flack  Our conversation reveals a great deal ndash indeed the answers could well be Kevrsquos Ten Commandments for those who may find themselves elevated beyond expectation.The first is Thou Shalt Not Buy A House Up The Road from Elton John.Bridges chooses to live in Glasgowin a nice, yet mixed income area. And when he strolls its streets he doesnrsquot take on the aura of the carefully-cloaked, head-down, move-fast Frankie Boyle, whose movements suggest Unemployed Terrorist Bomber. No, Bridges walks the dog in his shortsto the shops, at a regular pace. As an ordinary person would.ldquoIrsquove never been an extrovert, he says on the subject of recognition. ldquoIrsquove never chased the limelight. I was someone who was chucked out of school for being funny so I figured Irsquod try and do something positive with that. But then one day you realise yoursquore on the telly and start to panic about walking down the street.But he deals with it. Shorts on. Dug on lead. The price for living in a city where hersquos a comedy hero is worth paying. ldquoOh, aye, the positives outweigh the negatives, although at times I just want to go into the post office and not be recognised because at times the public feel an ownership. He adds with a chuckle: ldquoSix degrees of separation  In Glasgow itrsquos far less. Irsquove got uncles and cousins I never knew I had. But most people are nice. And at the same time, I donrsquot want to move to London. My family and friends are here and it would be really sad to leave them behind.But how does he cope being more minted than a Polo mint factory Second Commandment: Thou Shalt Not Become Gary Barlow.ldquoI have a socialist outlook yet I believe people should earn and try to be prosperous. Aye, Irsquoll get criticism for being a millionaire but Irsquom happy to pay  per cent tax in Scotland. A sip of coffee fuels a little anger. ldquoI look at the likes of Gary Barlow on Children In Need asking the public to send in money and find out he has his money in offshore accounts. To be honest, I really donrsquot know how he can sleep at nights.And what about St Bono of Dublin, who owned a chunk of a shopping centre in Lithuania, according to the Paradise Papers  ldquoWell, he and U never got to play the Hydro this year because I had it booked out, he says with a dark grin, his digit finger rising, . ldquoLook, I think having money is fine, so long as you pay your tax and yoursquore good to people.Third Commandment: Honour Thy Ma and Da. Bridges bought his parents a home in Clydebank said to be worth almost pound,. He is spectacularly generous to family and friends but does it become wearing when asked for a lend of pound, or pound ldquoA lot, he says with a wry smile. ldquoItrsquos a bit sad. You try and be good to people and they ask you for a certain amount and [when they get it] never mention it again. So what do you do  Irsquom doing  nights at the Hydro so how can I possibly go chasing them up  But then you learn. The money has been well spent in a sense because you know not to trust that person again. Therersquos never a next time.Bridges doesnrsquot pretend to fans hersquos not loaded. ldquoYou canrsquot do that, he maintains. In his new DVD he talks to the Hydro audience about doing  nights at pound a pop x , people. ldquoI have never m*********d over a sum before, he says, which brings huge laughs.Thatrsquos eight million quidrsquos worth of adulation. Yet, herersquos the thing: Bridges explains for most of his time on stage he can barely enjoy it.Fourth Commandment: Thou Shalt Always Retain a Sense of Squeaky Bum.ldquoItrsquos a good feeling being in front of so many people but you are still thinking lsquoThey could stop laughing here.rsquo You know you need to keep it going, and that feeling overrides the sense of joy you get from the laughs.Wow, but surely you have to allow some of this adulation to seep in  ldquoYes, a bit. Once the gig is up and running, you can relax a wee bit, yet yoursquore still working, trying to make the joke better, improvise . . .ldquoHerersquos the thing when you first start to sell out arenas you think someone is going to pull you aside and say, lsquoTimes, up!rsquo It hasnt happened, yet, you still have that wee bit of insecurity, that you could lose the audience. And it makes you work harder. But thatrsquos a good thing.Perhaps not always. Recently, Bridges walked off stage because he was being heckled. Now, there are critics who will say, lsquoJust keep going ndash thatrsquos what you get the big bucks for, Kevin.rsquo But itrsquos not that simple. Bridges doesnrsquot tell gags. He crafts delicate, cleverly woven tales. When the heckling starts his internal knitting is ripped. And you wouldnrsquot go to a theatre and heckle Anthony Sher during a soliloquy.Thou Shalt Avoid Twitter Storms Like the Plague.Bridges doesnrsquot look at social media during his concert runs in case it interferes with his head space. ldquoOne negative comment could derail me. AndIrsquom happy with the show I donrsquot need to read all the positives. Irsquove done comedy for  years and I donrsquot need a guy with a picture of an egg to tell me itrsquos shite. And the views on social media are extreme. Therersquos no middle ground discussion.Bridges is clearly an international-class worrier. The next Kevin Commandment reveals how this works in his favour. Work harder than a Snow White Dwarf to Get the Right Material.ldquoThere are times when I worry that Irsquoll never think of anything funny ever again, he admits. ldquoI feel it a lot. Itrsquos like writerrsquos block. You try so hard but nothing comes. And I donrsquot use other writers ndash thatrsquos why I only tour every few years.When he gets ideas he throws them down on notepads, train tickets. Bits of scrap. ldquoI will bounce ideas of people. Who  ldquoMy girlfriend. It drives her a bit mad, because we can be walking through the park, and Irsquoll tell her it, but shersquos getting it at the raw stage. He grins: ldquoWhen you give someone an idea and they say itrsquos s**** sometimes it gives you a twisted drive. I just think lsquoIrsquom going to show you. Irsquom going to make this funnyrsquo.rsquorsquoHe writes it up. He rewrites. The first outing for the joke is a small comedy club. ldquoIrsquom then standing next to blokes who have been doing stand-up for maybe a year. Theyrsquore novices. You go on the stage like one of them. Sure, the crowd will maybe give you a minutes grace because they recognise you, but once that minute is up you get judged on the laughs you produce. And thatrsquos when you knowthe new stuff will work. Itrsquos like doing your first gig again.He adds: ldquoBut you need to do this. I could die on my arse but at the same time I donrsquot want to go out on the big stage and do totally safe stuff. I canrsquot take the chance that I will go on to do material before , people and they come away thinking lsquoThat was OK.rsquoThe pressure is always on. To be better. To be funnier. But therersquos an immense pressure just to go about le without looking for the funny.Thou Shalt Let the Air into the Skull.ldquoAfter the  tour I took off on a trip to Madrid to take a course in Spanish, six weeks, six hours a day. And it really helped me to get my mind somewhere . I guess this sort of [displacement] activity is the human brainrsquos way of coping. But herersquos the funny thing. I had homework to do, to conjugate these Spanish verbs, but as I tried to get locked into this Irsquod be walking to the college in the morning and coming up with funny stories. He grins: ldquoIrsquod then go in and fail my test, but at the same Irsquod think, lsquoWell, comedy is my livelihood. Spanish is just a hobby.The course itself threw up comedy opportunity. ldquoI had to stand up in the morning and introduce myself, to say where yoursquore from and what you do. lsquoHi, Irsquom Kevin, from Glasgow.rsquo I didnrsquot want to say I was a comedian, or a lsquohumoristarsquo, but just at that moment I looked outside and saw a van, and on it was painted Electricistas. So I thought I would just say that I was an electrician."But a wee while later a Scottish and an English guy joined the class. And they recognised me and asked me for a selfie.He laughs: ldquoMeanwhile, the rest of the class were wondering why these two guys were asking an electrician for a selfie.ldquoI was telling my girlfriend about this and she laughed and said I should write that down. Then I thought how I could explain the selfies to the class  He laughs in recall: ldquoI reckoned I could have said Irsquom a celebrity electrician. Irsquom famous because Irsquove been on The Great British Rewire.The constant ided self ndash the need to come up with comedy and the need to shut down the need to come up with comedy ndash is challenging. But Bridges is Connolly-like in blending cleverly topical dilemmas with his own background.Thou Shalt Drink From The Well of Personal Experience.He does a hilarious routine aboutchatting on his mobile phone will walking the dog ndash and the dog skids to a halt, refusing to accept itrsquos not getting the attention it deserved. ldquoItrsquos a true story, he says, grinning. ldquoThe dog actually did that. And I tested the theory. I put the phone away, then walked, then took it out again. Sure enough, she pulled the lead tight.He also does a great routine about Joseph announcing news of Maryrsquos pregnancy to his mates on the building site. Once a Catholic... ldquoI donrsquot believe, but Irsquom hedging my bets, he says. ldquoIrsquom a kind of, lsquoWell Irsquoll find out when we diersquo type of guy. But some wummin called me a bigot after that gag.He had entered the world of the Easily Offended  ldquoOh aye! he agrees. ldquoThere are lots of people looking to take offence. You can download five apps to give you a complaint  these days, butyou donrsquot have much to say you have to come up with something.Bridgesrsquo success owes much to his avoidance of easy political targets. ldquoIt would be all too easy to say, for example, that Trump is an arse and a moron. You have to do it with a bit of subtlety. What Bridges does instead is take one of President Trumprsquos insaneideas such as arming teachers in the wake of school shootings and personalises the argument. ldquoIrsquove had teachers who couldnrsquot use a VHS recorder, never mind a semi-automatic weapon, says Bridges on stage, then rfing on the theme: ldquoI think everybodyrsquos had a mad techie teacher.Thou Shalt Appreciate the Value of Self-Deprecation.Take the current vogue of those who complain about lsquoshamingrsquo. The schoolboy Kevin was a worried, anxious child who was called Fattyboomboom. ldquoYou just sucked it up. Yes, fat-shaming existed when you were at school. You got fat-shamed, skinny-shamed, speccy-shamed, buck-teeth, big-eared your-darsquos-an-alkie-shamed. You even got Adidas-four-stripe-trainers shame.And you would accept it or you got a, lsquoCannae take a shaming shame.rsquoYes, he has taken a political stancebut itrsquos measured and continually recalibrated.Thou Shalt Rip the Backside Out of all Political Gods.In  he saidthere was an independence vote hersquod probably vote Yes. ldquoBut I donrsquot know how Irsquod feel about that now, given the mess wersquore in given the Brexit situation. Itrsquos made me think about how Scotland would bewe left the rest of the UK.His tone darkens. ldquoIrsquom only  but Irsquove never seen people so angry as theyrsquove been in the past few years.Thou Shall Not Take Up with a Golddigger Who Will Selfie You Right into the Tabloids.He references his girlfriend, Kerry, a great deal, a manager in a classy Glasgow restaurant cafe of whom he said: ldquoWorks, like, -hour shts. Unthinkable! Clearly shersquos a rock. But what about when you have a fall out, Kevin  Does personal le impact upon stage performance  ldquoEverybodyrsquos got to show up for work, evenyoursquore in a bad mood, whether itrsquos come from having a leak in your kitchen or whatever. Butthere is something in my head what I do is have  minutes shutdown before a show, so Irsquoll skip ndash I go to a boxing gym ndash and listen to music. Itrsquos an escape from the pressure. You canrsquot take a problem out there in front of , people.The job of being Kevin Bridges is not just about telling very funny stories. Itrsquos about keeping himself in a safe zone whereby the stories will continue to emerge. This involves making sure friends are real, eventhey are showbiz stars. Let them lay on your floor in a sleeping bag. Jack Whitehall, he reveals, once stayed over at his house in Clydebank. ldquoI took him to a Celtic game and he missed his flight back to London. He laughs. ldquoWe had a sleepover, on the floor of my bedroom. My mum made him a roll rsquonrsquo tottie scone in the morning.Is that the final commandment for comedy longevity  ldquoAye, Spanish lessons and tottie scones, he says, laughing.Kevin Bridges, The Brand New Tour ndash Live is out now on DVD and Digital Download. He will be signing copies of the DVD at HMV, Argyle Street, Glasgow, December  at pm.

title: Forget lame dames    pantos are moving with the times
story: Look closely at this yearrsquos Christmas schedule, however, and yoursquoll find a dferent, more modern approach to gender politics in many theatres as they seek to redress the balance and offer an inclusive and representative repertoire.Indeed, one might say this yearrsquos shows are filled with ass-kicking girls. Crucially, however, those behind the productions ndash many of whom are women ndash are keen to ensure this approach doesnrsquot come at the expense of boys, or indeed the fun, excitement and laughter that have always been the heart of Christmas shows.Gender politics was very much in the mind of director Eleanor Rhode as she worked on Wendy and Peter Pan for the Lyceum Theatre in Edinburgh. The clue to her outlook is in the name of the production ndash Wendy takes centre stage.ldquoPeter Pan is the most wonderful story but traditionally Wendy has always been a bit wet, explains Ms Rhodes, who last year wowed audiences and critics alike with her production of Boudica at Shakespearersquos Globe in London. ldquoIn this show she throws off the shackles ndash Wendy is definitely the protagonist.ldquoPeter Pan has a big part to play too, obviously, but the show asks some fundamental questions about why it always has to be the girl that is the character looking after everyone, the prim and proper one, rather than the one who gets to have adventures.ldquoBut the production isnrsquot just about the fact that women are as capable as men and need to have a stronger voice. Itrsquos also about the roles we force men and boys into.Ms Rhode was inspired to work in the theatre after seeing Shakespearersquos Twelfth Night as a child, a play renowned for its strong female roles.ldquoI remember how exciting it was to see someone who looked like me on the stage, someone I could connect with, she says. ldquoA girl was at the heart of the action ndash she was the strong one, with all the best lines, leading the story. That was really important for me.As the recent furore over the first female Doctor Who ndash played by Jodie Whittaker ndash revealed, some are still critical of what they perceive as equality being forced upon society, especially when it means ldquomessing with the classics. How would the director respond to the accusation that presenting a new, more feminist Wendy betrays JM Barriersquos original ldquoFor me,you deliver the goods with an entertaining piece of theatre that has something to say, no one will go home disappointed. This is a show with a massive heart and everything people love about Peter Pan is there.More enlightened gender politics isa theme across the board. Perth Theatrersquos Snow White doesnrsquot rely on a man for her happy ending, while at the Kingrsquos Theatre in Glasgow, Widow Twankey finally gets to be a woman ndash in the shape of Elaine C Smith, no less.Scots actor Shauna Macdonald, who is directing a cast of young people in Snow White and the Seven Dwarves in Portobello, Edinburgh, was also keen to update traditional stereotypes.ldquoFor this piece wersquove ignored gender, in a good way, says the Bafta Scotland winner, star of films such The Decent and Filth, and TV dramas such as Spooks and The Cry. ldquoThe dwarves are a mix of genders and all have moustaches. It doesnrsquot matter who wears what and who ends up with whom. Therersquos a great line at one point: lsquoI identy as a princess therefore I should be treated as onersquo. We have fun with gender politics and fluidity, issues that young people are very wise to and well way ahead of their parents on. I have three daughters andI tried to read them a fairy tale with a princess being saved by her one true love, a prince, they wouldnrsquot be interested.ldquoThis a Christmas show and the purpose is to entertain, not educate. But letrsquos bend the rules and have some fun ndash who made up the rules, anyway Ms Macdonald, from Edinburgh, who also voices gadget-mad Professor Squawkencluck in CBBC cartoon Dangermouse, believes women still face institutionalised sexism in the entertainment industry.ldquoAs a female actor itrsquos a battle trying to get a good role with strong character development that challenges you as a performer, where you are not just someonersquos girlfriend, she says. ldquoCommunity theatre for young people is so important as it can have a positive impact on their choices in le.According to fellow director Rosalind Sydney, positive role models can influence even very young children. Ms Sydney is directing an all-female Christmas production at Glasgowrsquos Tron Theatre, aimed at the under-six age group.Remember December follows Flora, a forgetful little girl who has forgotten to post her letter to Santa. ldquoWhen conceiving the show it was important to reinforce the idea that girls can take the lead, be brave, physical and strong, explains the director. ldquoFlora scales a mountain, goes skiing and paddles on river rapids. The bond between grandparent and child is very important to this show, and Flora and her granny are active, physical people.ldquoBoys should have good female role models, too. I have two young sons and they are not put off by female-centred narratives or female protagonists. But gender-biased attitudes are embedded deeply into our society and when you rock the status quo people can feel a bit scared. Wersquore not taking roles models away from boys ndash wersquore just showing that it shouldnrsquot matter.Ms Sydney is keenly aware of the unique place pantos and festive shows have in our hearts ndash and the opportunities they present.ldquoChristmas shows are particularly important because for many people, especially children, itrsquos the only time of the year they come to the theatre, she says. ldquoItrsquos vital that theatre makers make the right choices.Wendy and Peter Pan is at the Lyceum in Edinburgh until anuary . Snow White and the Seven Dwarves is at Bellfield, Portobello, from December  -. Remember December is at the Tron Theatre till December .

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: SCOTTISH Tory justice spokesman Liam Kerr has been typecast as a cadaverous lawyer since arriving at Holyrood. But it seems he has unexpected depths. At the recent Herald Scottish Politician of the Year Awards he was shocked to be outed in a video as a former ldquochain-smoking Goth, earning him good-natured pelters from others on his table. Unspun hears he was so secretly chuffed, he is now trying to obtain a copy of the clip for posterity.IAN Blackford is, in his own words to MPs, ldquojust a simple crofter with  acres. Is there gold under them, we wonder  When the SNPrsquos Westminster leader met former Nat MP Margaret Ferrier near Strathpeffer last week, she posted a snap of them on Twitter. In doing so she revealed Mr Blackford, a former Edinburgh banker who tweeds it up in his Skye seat, swanks around, crofter-style, in a luxurious Range Rover convertible. To the Peatmobile, Batman!ALSO on Twitter, SNP minister Christina McKelvie had a novel take on Small Business Saturday. Finance Secretary Derek Mackay called it ldquoan excellent opportunity to rediscover local, independent traders and kick-start your Christmas shopping. I would encourage everyone to remember their independent traders and buy local. Ms McKelvie tweeted: ldquoI woke up early this morning, have completed a substantial online Christmas shop. Oops.SCOTTISH Labour and the TSSA rail union are always banging on about public support for renationalising ScotRail, but just how popular is it  Not much, judging by a leaked email to two Labour MSPs. ldquoMorning comrades! wrote the unionrsquos press officer. ldquoCould you give this petition a signature and pass it around the other MSPs to get theirs on it too please  Trying to get a new Peoplersquos Petition for ScotRail nationalisation to look healthy and popular before I release it to the media. Cheers! Still, at latest they get points for trying. Points, geddit GREENOCK Nat MSP Stuart McMillan celebrated St Andrewrsquos Day in unique style, cutting the ribbon for the "grand opening" of a coffin shop. Adverts for the unmissable event at a local funeral directors were enticing. ldquoThere will be, cakes and coffee - everyone welcome to come down for a look around. Except in the refrigerated area, presumably. Who says politics isnrsquot glamorous SCOTTISH Labour leader Richard Leonard attended a lunch with journalists on Thursday, where he faced brutal questions about his partys woes. But he still managed a few gags of his own. Labour spinner Andrew Liddles incongruous Ruth Davidson biography is currently sitting at , in the Amazon bestseller list, he gleefully revealed. But no matter, he added ndash thats still , places above Labour MSP Neil Findlays book, Socialism and Hope. Good to see the partys golden touch extends to literature.

title: blindness-causing-condition-on-the-rise-in-fife-amid-obesity-epidemic
story: The crisis has been blamed for unusually high rates of a blood pressure condition which typically affects overweight young women.Researchers found that levels of Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertensionin Fe were two to six times higher than would be expected, compared with similar developed nations.Read more: Huge cave system could be Scotlands longest and most spectacularHeadaches are the most common symptom of the condition and are caused by high pressure within the brain which can damage the optic nerves. In around -% of patients, IIH leads to irreversible sight loss.Scientists from the University of St Andrews collected data on all patients who were newly diagnosed with IIH within the ophthalmology department in NHS Fe over a  month period, from August  to July .A total of  patients were diagnosed with the condition, translating to an incidence of . cases per , people in Fe.Previous estimates of the annual incidence of IIH worldwide y from . to . per ,.All patients in the Fe study except one were female, and all were overweight. The average body mass index was  - clinically obese.Read more: Anger and confusion as O network remains crashedHeadache was the most common presenting symptom among the patients, but one patient also complained of visual symptoms.Three patients presented with no symptoms but were found to have swollen optic discs during a routine sight test.Dr Colin Goudie, an Ophthalmology Registrar at the Princess Alexandra Eye Pavilion in Edinburgh, who conducted the research, said: ldquoThe incidence of IIH in Fe was signicantly higher than previous estimates and we believe this is due to the high levels of obesity in the region."We found that the incidence of IIH in Fe was between two and six times higher than previously reported from other studies performed in similarly developed nations.In , % of the adult population in Scotland were recorded as being overweight - measured as a BMI in excess of  - with with % being clinically obese. Of the patients in the Fe study, more than three-quarters were clinically obese and all the rest were overweight.Read more: Leading bariatric surgeon says % of his patients cant cook a simple mealDr Andrew Blaikie, Senior Lecturer in the School of Medicine at the University of St Andrews and Consultant Ophthalmologist with NHS Fe, who oversaw the project said:ldquoScotland has one of the worst records for obesity in the developed world and the prevalence of obesity in Fe is higher than the Scottish average."We are in the midst of an obesity epidemic andthis continues we will see IIH becoming more common, increasing the risk of a small but signicant number of young people losing vision.He added: ldquoAs being overweight is the cause of the disease the primary treatment is to lose weight and achieve a normal BMI."This can be augmented with medicines and sometimes surgery to prevent any long-term damage to sight and improve symptoms of headache.ldquoHowever, a group of patients exist who can still develop rapidly progressive and permanent vision loss despite prompt treatment.

title: christmas-comes-early-as-airlines-slash-cost-of-flights
story: No-frills giant Ryanair led discounting this week with some weekendfares lower than the price of a cup of continental coffee and a bun.The Irish carrier was offering to take passengers to and from both Ireland and Germany this weekend for less than pound.Air fares watchers say canny travellers can pick up deals - even for the school holidays to winter sunshine destinations like the Canaries.Ryanair at one point had s from Prestwick to the Tenere for the Christmas and New Year week for pound and s of pound to Fuerteventura for the fortnight up to the holidays.Discounting is common in the weeks before and after Christmas - but prices usually soar during what is the busiest period of the aviation year. Industry insiders are reluctant to talk up low fares amid concerns that some airlines may not be able to keep Scottish routes profitable.A spokesman for Edinburgh Airport said: ldquoEarly December is traditionally a quiet time for aviation and therefore a great time to get a good deal on flights.ldquoCanny shoppers or those wishing to get away before a hectic Christmas are all picking up great bargains.ldquoScottish passengers have the choice of more destinations than ever and wersquore seeing increasing numbers of passengers travelling year on year.The pound collapsed the early morning of the Brexit vote and has been under pressure ever since. The UK is due to leave the EU at the end of March with fears rising of a no deal scenario and its devastating impact on Sterling.Last month holiday operator Thomas Cook - whose planes do a lot of the heavy lting of tourists from Scotland to sunshine destinations - announced that its profits had noseed after lower exchange rate and higher summer UK temperatures.Also last month regional airline FlyBe, amid low profits, a weak pound and Brexit uncertainty, put itself up for sale.Throwaway fares - prices so low would-be travellers book them on impulse - might sound like good news. And any airline will discount to put bums on seats. However, travel experts stress that the cost of a holiday - in sterling terms - is still high. You might get to Fuerteventura this month for the cost of apeak train fare from Glasgow to Edinburgh. Yet when you get there you will have to pay in euros for accommodation and food.The prospect of a clf-edge departure from the EU worries continental holiday providers. The head of Spainrsquos national tourism agency in the UK said a no-deal Brexit would be lsquoa disasterrsquo for his country.Discounts are particularly steep on flights to Germany, Ireland Scandinavia, where costs for Scottish tourists with pounds in their pocket are particularly high and where the weather is far less warm than the CanariesNorwegian this month has s to Copenhagen, Oslo and Stockholm for under pound. Ryanair had s to some of same cities - but not always the same airports - for between pound and pound.The low-cost airline this week was offering December weekend s to the Baian city of Memmingen for pound. and Derry in Northern Ireland for pound. from Edinburgh. Fares have since edged up to around pound each.Next weekend flights to the sunny Canarian island of Lanzarote are down to pound , leaving on Friday and ing on Monday.Industry insiders stressed that the airline recently cut the size of its free hand luggage and was therefore in a position to offer lower fares. Its change, which came in to place on November , has angered some consumer groups. One Spanish organisation said the move was ldquoabusive.Experts also said travellers should look out for more deals in January - when EasyJet has s from Glasgow to Venice for pound, including a more generous hand luggage allowance than its rival.For the week beginning January  Ryanair has fares from Edinburgh for poundto Alicante and Fuerteventura, pound to Porto, pound to Dublin, pound to Derry, according to the Scottish-based fares comparison site SkyScanner.For the same week, SkyScanner showsfares of pound from Prestwick to Malta on Ryanair, pound from Glasgow to Dusseldorf on Eurowings and pound to New York via London on British Airways.Hugh Aitken, of SkyScanner, explained: ldquoIn most cases, airline pricing works in tranches ndash a limited number of very low prices, for example, may be available for a limited number of seats.ldquoThere are generally multiple lsquofare bandsrsquoavailable for each flight. Once a certain fare band has been booked up, the next one will be displayed, and this will likely be at a higher price, as you might expect with a supply-demand model.ldquoAs an example, The Herald found a Prestwick to Tenere flight for pound ndash the price is now pound, most probably as the lower fare band has been booked up.ldquoAirlines want to ensure they maximise loads and encourage travel, so travellers may additionally see lower prices and sales for travel during January: this tends to be a slightly quieter month when compared to peak holiday times such as Easter.The flip-side of the falling pound is that more people from overseas are travelling to holiday in Scotland. Even flights to sunshine destinations - such as Italy and Spain - once filled with Scots are seeing growing numbers of inbound passengers, say insiders. VisitScotland is trying to market Scotland as a winter destination.

title: analysis-the-future-of-the-country-theresa-may-and-the-tory-government-hangs-on-next-weeks-vote
story: After the drama of the last seven days at Westminster, next weekrsquos looks set to be even more tumultuous.As some  senior ministers were dispatched to the four corners of the nation to sell the Prime Ministerrsquos bullet-ridden Plan, No  was asked why only . What better things did others have to do given the depth of the crisis that the UK Government is now engulfed in As for the Prime Minister, she was ensconced in her Berkshire bunker, no doubt contemplating the twists and turns that the next few days might bring and whether she will still be in Downing St by the end of it.Mrs May could also be forgiven for watching Saturday nightrsquos Sunday papers review from behind her Maidenhead sofa as they are likely to be full of screaming headlines about insurmountable parliamentary numbers, threats of ministerial resignations and impending confidence votes in her and her government.Of course, given the off-on and then off-again saga of the televised debate, the PM can now at least spend Sunday evening watching Strictly while her Labour counterpart sits glued to the final of Irsquom a Celebrity.But it will be an all-too-brief respite from Brexit and its political ramications in the coming days.Tory Remainer Justine Greening, the former Education Secretary, warned her party thatit continued to be consumed by Brexit, then it would lose the support of Middle England to another party that occupied the centre and centre-right ground. And she said thatthe Tories did not change, they would never have another landslide election victory.ldquoThe Conservative party has failed to really change, declared Ms Greening. ldquoItrsquos almost like weve got this Old Testament of how Margaret Thatcher did politics and, of course, then it was absolutely current and relevant for Britain but not enough people in our party are looking at who are we now whats Conservatism in the st century stand for now, the London MP told the BBCrsquos Nick Robinson in his Political Thinking podcast.Oh and she also said she would be prepared to consider throwing her hat in the ringMrs May left her leadership role willingly or otherwise next week.On Monday, after a weekend of what s, MPsto Westminster to debate the Brexit Bill and the Union.There will be lots of talk about Northern Ireland and the impenetrable backstop to the backstop issue as well as about Scotland and the possible knock-on effect of a second independence referendum. I can hear Brenda from Bonnyrigg now.In the past few days there has been serious talk of Mrs May pulling the vote. Advice that came not only from some of her ministers but also from Sir Graham Brady, who chairs the  backbench committee. Indeed, Tony Blair waded in to echo the advice, noting there was no point in crashing into a ldquobrick wall at speed.What has apparently irked the PMrsquos closest colleagues is that when she stonewalls in public about a Plan B, she does the same to them in private.Now it could well be in this unpredictable dimension we call Brexit that Mrs May pulls off an outstanding parliamentary escape on Tuesday that would outshine even Harry Houdini. But I very much doubt it.So what happens when MPs pull the plug on the PMrsquos Brexit Plan  There is a suggestion that those kind souls in Brussels will offer a helping hand and say the EU is willing to extend Article  for a couple of months to allow the UK more time to pull itself together. Yet the deal agreed last month is legally binding and unchangeable. So it is unlikely there will be any sympathy on the continent.Mrs May has been looking at other options, flying a parliamentary kite about giving MPs a say nearer the time in spring  when the UK and EU will have to determine whether or not a trade agreement can be agreed by the December of that year. Probably not.So MPs could at that point choose to see the dreaded backstop introduced from January  or vote to extend the transition, which would maintain the status quo for however many more months including compliance with the loathed Common Fisheries Policy. Which, of course, would send Scottish Conservatives into a blue funk, not least David Mundell, the Scottish Secretary.If the PM goes ldquodown in a blaze of glory, as one colleague suggested she was determined to do, what happens Her suggestion of a ldquoparliamentary lock has all been about damage limitation trying to peel away as many Tory rebels as she can to keep the numbers manageable. Anything below  is just about manageable anything above it becomes trickier. Anything above  and the smell of toast will be in the air at Westminster.Labourrsquos Sir Keir Starmer has already suggested that it is ldquoinevitable that Labour would next Wednesday put down a confidence vote in the Conservative Government. But the Democratic Unionists have already indicated they would support the Tories in that scenario.So the prospect of another general election would then evaporate.But Mrs May will not be out of the woods yet. If the Tory rebellion on the meaningful vote on the PMrsquos Brexit Plan is more than , then the prospect of another confidence vote, a Conservative one in Mrs Mayrsquos leadership, looms large.If this were to happen, then, once again, it would be about the scale of the rebellion.Already, there are suggestions of backbenchers are being nodded and winked at about future government rolesthey backed a certain senior colleague should Mrs May be history by next Friday.The names being bandied around the oak-led corridors include Jeremy Hunt, Sajid Javid and Amber Rudd all, of course, Remainers. Then there is Boris, waiting in the wings, and still waiting for the rugby ball to come out of the scrum.It should be remembered that the ultimate choice in any leadership contest goes to the Conservative Party membership and the grassroots appear far more pro-Leave than some of their MPs at Westminster.As the Brexit deal vote approaches on Tuesday, it is well to note that we are living in extraordinary political times. The countryrsquos future is up in the air as, indeed, is Mrs Mayrsquos and the Conservative Governmentrsquos.The moment of truth comes on Tuesday evening but, given the nature of this particular political beast, therersquoll be another one along soon after. Westminster has rarely been so unpredictable.

title: jeremy-corbyn-says-labour-government-would-consider-delaying-brexit-to-get-better-deal
story: The Opposition leader told Sky News: "If we go into government straight away, we would start negotiating straight away. If it meant holding things a bit longer to do it, of course."Askedhe could see an argument for extending Article , Mr Corbyn replied: "Thatrsquos an argument that may come up."Brandon Lewis, the Tory Chairman, said: ldquoCorbynrsquos latest U-turn, admitting Labour would delay exiting the EU, shows he cannot be trusted to keep his promise to respect the referendum result all he would do is take us back to square one."The Labour leaders remarks came as Theresa May faces the most important week of her political career on which hang not only her own future but also that of the Conservative Government and Brexit itself.As some  ministers took to the four corners of the country to sell the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, No  made clear there was no sense of there being just five days to save Mrs Mayrsquos premiership. Her spokesman insisted she and her closest colleagues were fully focused on winning Tuesdayrsquos crunch vote.Yet the parliamentary arithmetic continues to point in one direction: a humiliating defeat for the PM and her Brexit Plan.Mrs May was warned that she could yet face a string of resignations by ministerial aidesshe did not make last-minute changes to her proposed deal a suggestion from Mike Wood, the Parliamentary Private Secretary to Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary.The Midlands MP told thehe had "big issues" with the Northern Ireland backstop and would resignthere were not enough "changes and reassurances" before Tuesdays vote to allow him to support the PMrsquos Plan.He argued other PPSs could follow suit. "You can obviously see there have been a number of PPSs who have spoken in favour of the Government this week. A clear majority will vote with the Government on Tuesday.But he added: "There are others who have a range of questions and concerns that they will want to be resolved before making their decision.In Belfast as part of the tranche of ministerial visits, David Lidington, the PMrsquos de facto deputy, insisted the Governments confidence and supply deal with the Democratic Unionists remained intact."The DUP have made it clear that they see the confidence and supply agreement as continuing."As with any minority Government there are going to be squalls and dficulties in a Parliament where the Government does not have an automatic majority in either House but that is not something new to British history," said the Cabinet Office Minister.However, Tory sources suggested the relationship between the DUP and Mrs May had irretrievably broken down as the Northern Irish party now regarded her as ldquoduplicitous.One Conservative MP claimed the DUP would make clear ahead of any Tory confidence vote that its confidence and supply arrangement would only continue with another Conservative leader."The DUP want her head on a plate," declared the backbencher.In other developments:*John Sentamu, the Archbishop of York, called for people to join him in a three-day prayer vigil ahead of Tuesdayrsquos Commons vote.*Boris Johnson, the former Foreign Secretary, suggested the PMs Brexit deal was similar to the ldquokind of diktat that might be imposed on a defeated side in a war it would, he argued, lead to France using it to "plunder" UK fishing waters.*Fresh splits emerged in the campaign for another EU referendum as Liberal Democrats tabled an amendment calling for another poll but the Peoplersquos Vote campaign branded the move ldquodeeply unhelpful as they want Mrs Mays deal to collapse first to ensure there is maximum support for another vote on EU membership.*This weekend campaigners predict thousands of supporters for a Peoplersquos Vote will be taking to the streets in cities and towns across Scotland.*Labourrsquos Stephen Kinnock, a leading Remainer, claimed ldquoat least  Cabinet ministers were backing the so-called Norway-Plus option but the Peoplersquos Vote campaign released a report on why it would not work and could make the Brexit crisis even worse. Senior Norwegian politicians and businesses figures also rejected Norway-Plus, saying it was ldquoneither in Norway nor the UKrsquos interest. Britain would need Norwayrsquos permission to join the EFTA club.*A poll said almost two-thirds of voters[ per cent] thought it would be bad for the UK to leave the EU under the terms of the May Plan, including  per cent of Conservatives. Only  per cent thought the PMrsquos deal would be good for Britain.

title: amateur-enthusiasts-record-15000-scottish-trees
story: Now the Woodland Trust has reached a major milestone ndash recording its ,th Scottish tree. As old as Bonnie Prince Charlie, the sweet chestnut they noted is at Murthly Castle in Perthshire.Kylie Harrison Mellor, the Trustrsquos citizen science officer, said the historic recording is more than  years old and an important marker for the organisation.She said: ldquoIdentying where ancient trees are takes us one step closer to giving them the care and protection they need.ldquoSo todayrsquos recording of the ,th tree in Scotland is really worth celebrating ndash and so are the efforts of the dedicated band of tree recorders and veriers who do this important work.The Ancient Tree Inventory took root as the Heritage Lottery funded Ancient Tree Hunt in January  and the first tree recorded in Scotland was an ancient sweet chestnut at Roslin Chapel, Midlothian.The system works in two stages: firstly, volunteers record trees secondly, these are then checked by specially trained veriers. Around  people have recorded trees since the project began and Scotland presently has five veriers.The UKrsquos ancient trees have no automatic right of protection. There is no equivalent to Scheduled Ancient Monument status, which important archaeological sites have.The Woodland Trust says that ldquothe famous Fortingall Yew highlights the disparity.Found growing in the churchyard of the Perthshire village which shares its name, it is among the oldest trees in Europe ndash modern experts estimate the tree is between , and , years old, although others believe it could be a remnant of a post-Roman Christian site dating back , years.According to folklore, Pontius Pilate ndash the Roman governor who oversaw the crucixion of Jesus ndash was born in its shade and played there as a child.But the Trust points out that it is the wall around the tree that attracts formal legal protection, rather than the tree itself.ldquoAncient trees are as much a part of our heritage as stately homes, cathedrals and works of art, but they donrsquot get the same protection, Ms Harrison Mellor adds.Vital statistics of the Murthly Castle tree were taken on Thursday afternoon by Judy Dowling from St Andrews, Joan Sneddon from Largo, Noel Fojut from Berwickshire, Clair McFarlan from Dumfries and Lorna Holl from Balmaha.It was recorded with a remarkable trunk girth of . metres. The tree itself is estimated to be more than  years old. Ms Dowling, who is lead verier for Scotland said: ldquoIt is amazing to reach this milestone, but we still have lots to do.ldquoWe hear about new trees all the time and I always have my eyes peeled wherever I go around the country. It takes you to some amazing places. I have just loved being a part of this.Welcoming the tree hunters to Castle Murthly Estate, Thomas Steuart Fothringham said: ldquoWe are delighted our sweet chestnut is the ,th tree to go on the inventory.ldquoThe designed landscape has been a feature at Murthly for half a millennium and continues to be highly valued.There are  trees which are so iconic they have their own inidual names such as Capon Oak, Mar Lodge Granny Pine, Drumlanrig Sycamore, Rizziorsquos Chestnut and Glen Lyon Ash.In October, a spruce tree on the Isle of Eriskay in the Outer Hebrides was named Scotlandrsquos Tree of the Year.Nettyrsquos Tree was nominated in the Woodland Trust competition by Eoina Wilson, who lives in Inverness but originally comes from the island. Judges chose six trees from public nominations which were then put to an online vote.The spruce was, until recent times, the only tree on the windswept island.It was planted more than  years ago by the poet, priest and land rights activist Father Allan McDonald, whose best-known poem was Eilein na hrsquoOige ndash The Island of the Young.It is named after Netty MacDonald, who lived on the nearby croft and encouraged all the islandrsquos children to play on the tree as their cries and laughter reminded her of her own family who had grown up and moved away to find work on the mainland.A map of all the recorded trees can be viewed at ati.woodlandtrust.org.uk.

title: how-secrets-of-12th-century-scots-castle-were-lost-in-the-mists-of-time
story: The exploration of Mote of Urr in Dumfries and Galloway spanned three years and dug into  years of Scottish history. Perhaps given such a vast timescale, there was no urgent need to share the findings.Indeed, itrsquos only now,  years after the meticulous excavation took place and possibly hindered by the lead archaeologistrsquos well-known sluggish approach to putting his research into print, that the fine details of excavations have finally been published.The dig at the th-century Norman motte and bailey castle site at Mote of Urr, near Dalbeattie ndash said to be one of the most extensive sites of its kind in Scotland ndash were undertaken in  and , and led by Brian Hope-Taylor, one of the UKrsquos most revered archaeologists and a familiar face on s television history programmes.The intention was to uncover relics that could point to the daily le of the wooden castle and the identities of the occupants of the two-hectare site over hundreds of years which, despite its scale and prominence on the landscape, were largely lost in time.Buthistorians and locals were eagerly awaiting news of the secrets lurking at the curious bulging mound remains at Mote of Urr, they would be sadly disappointed.And it would take the exhaustive piecing together of Hope-Taylorrsquos notes and  years after his death before the work could finally be shared.ldquoBrian Hope-Taylor was a charismatic and perspicacious scholar, says Professor Barbara Crawford of the University of St Andrews and University of the Highlands and Islands, in the newly published report. ldquoLike some other archaeologists Hope-Taylor did not find it easy to write up the results of his excavations for final publication.Famed for his work on Anglo-Saxon and early medieval sites in Scotland and England, he undertook excavations at Bamburgh, Lindisfarne and York Minster, one of his key interests was in motte-and-bailey castles, wooden structures built on top of a raised earthwork such as at Mote of Urr.But archaeology fees paid little ndash perhaps a reason for his sluggish approach to report writing ndash and Hope-Taylor, who had also received a ldquosevere dressing down from superiors over delays in reporting findings from a major excavation of an Anglo Saxon site at Yeavering in Northumberland, is thought to have shelved certain projects either because they failed to produce obvious results or because he sought others which may have been more lucrative.His death in  led to scores of papers relating to several archaeological excavations being retrieved from his house and garage, with many relating to Scottish excavations being delivered to the Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Scotland ndash now Historic Environment Scotland.Funding from Historic Scotlandand English Heritage, meant they could be finally assessed, sorted, conserved and, at last in the case of Mote of Urr, published. The work, which has been supplemented by an exhaustive historical investigation by Professor Richard Oram of Stirling University, sheds fresh light on the ownership of the site down the centuries even though it reveals Hope-Taylor found a surprising lack of material to support existing understanding of its origins.For although records point to the castle being under the possession of Walter de Berkeley, the th-century Great Chamberlain of William , Hope-Taylorrsquos team of archaeologists could not find any pottery linked to that era.ldquoHope-Taylor dated the construction and earliest occupation at Mote of Urr to the late th century, with continued occupation into the th century, says David Perry of Alder Archaeology, who worked on the report.Catherine Smith, who worked on analysing bone fragments found by Hope-Taylorrsquos team, said he may have deliberately delayed writing his report of the excavation with the intention of ing in the future.She said: ldquoHope-Taylor was a very eminent archaeologist and itrsquos possible that he was saying to himself that hersquod just finish one project and go back to Mote of Urr, but never did.ldquoWe donrsquot know why he didnrsquot finish it. Itrsquos possible that he didnrsquot discover enough about it at the time and he knew it would require more work.While Hope-Taylorrsquos records of the excavation are said to be ldquoan important contribution to the study of mottes in Scotland, Mr Perry said they raise more questions than answers.ldquoFollowing his investigations of the motte in  and  Hope-Taylor had originally planned toto Mote of Urr in order to excavate its surrounding bailey. Had he been able to do so, some of the questions regarding the period during which the whole site was occupied and how the motte related to others in Scotland and the north of England might have been answered.ldquoOr, as is so often the case in archaeology, yet more questions might have been raised.

title: green-energy-revolution-unfolds-yards-from-celtic-park
story: The first hole, which was drilled yesterday just across the road from Celtic Park, is part of a project with so much research potential that scientists, academics and businesses from all over the world will be looking to Glasgow to inform the energy projects of tomorrow.The  boreholes across the city will record data as part of the UK Geoenergy Observatoriesproject andsuccessful could see parts of the city being heated from old mine workings and the technology to be exported to other cities across the globe.The pound million project will record information about the rocks to an unprecedented level, with some going down almost  metres into the ground.The East End sits on the old mines which contain warm water, which have the potential to be used to heat homes and businesses in the area.This data will then be shared for free to anyone who wants to access it, meaning students, academics, scientists, and businessmen across the world can access this data and use it to inform their own research and innovations.Zoe Shipton, professor of geological engineering at the University of Strathclyde, said: ldquoBig science questions need big pieces of kit. Physicists have their CERNand we have our UKGEOS and this is going to be a laboratory with a -year design le.ldquoWe can rarely carry out a controlled experiment in the way that chemists and physicists are able to do. This is what UKGEOS will allow us to do ndash wersquore going to characterise a cubic kilometre of rock in Glasgow and know the characteristics of the rock to an incredible degree.ldquoWersquoll have sensors down those boreholes that listen to the earth and hear the changes that happen where we have earthquakes. This sensor going just across the road will be able to hear earthquakes from across the planet, and ones nearerby as the seasons change ndash or where somebody scores at Celtic Park.ldquoIf we are going to meet the demands of the Paris Treaty and decrease or reliance on fossil fuels and increase the ability of ourselves to power our homes and heat our homes, and run our economy on renewable energy, we need to make it possible for businesses to come in.Apart from using hot water from the earth to heat peoplersquos homes, geological research from this site may have many more applications for creating a greener way of living.David Manning, professor of soil science at Newcastle Universitym, said: ldquoIn this country wersquove been mining for over , years, even before the Romans in Cornwall we were trading tin to the Phoenicians. We need to take all that knowledge from oil and gas and take it across to geothermal so that we can run with that given itrsquos carbon free.ldquoHot water coming from the inside of the earth can be used to heat peoplersquos houses. Wersquore also interested in energy storage ndash what came up can come down, so it is possible for us to put heat from the surface into underground stores and take it back out again when we need it in winter. Hot summers can be captured, put underground and taken out again."As well as asking the big scientic questions, which could revolutionise the way we think about heating or homes and storing energy, the boreholes will also be exploring the possibility of heating the local area of the East End and Clyde Gateway.Although renewable energy is good at generating electricity, heat is more dficult to transport and store. Last year Scotland produced only six per cent of its heat from renewable sources, compared to % of its electricity.Ian Manson, chief executive of Clyde Gateway, said: ldquoThe East End has a history of great industry and to regenerate the area we need to look at the industries of the future. We hope this project will create a greater focus on renewables and bring engineering companies and jobs to the area.ldquoWersquove got the target of achieving , jobs for this area, wersquove already attracted , ndash some of which are in renewables.ldquoWersquore looking at the low hundreds, but therersquos no reason why we shouldnrsquot be aiming at the thousands for jobs in this area.

title: kt-tunstall-and-amy-macdonald-to-perform-at-sleep-in-the-park
story: The singers will start the night in Aberdeen before being taken by helicopter to gigs in the other participating cities ndash Dundee, Glasgow and Edinburgh.Organisers of Sleep in the Park hope to beat the pound million raised by last yearrsquos single event in Edinburgh, which had , participants.A message from JoshA message from Josh ahead of tomorrows Sleep in the Park events.Posted by Social Bite on Friday, December , The cash goes towards tackling homelessness through housing projects and employment programmes, and supporting those on the streets with shelters and hot food and drink.KT Tunstall, who released her latest album, Wax, in October, tweeted: ldquoSo glad to be taking part in @SocialBite_ #SleepInThePark on Saturday to raise a ton of money and awareness to help Scotlandrsquos homeless.Comedian Fred MacAulay is hosting the Edinburgh event, with a performance by Lulu and a bedtime story from Trainspotting author Irvine Welsh in West Princes Street Gardens.Frightened Rabbit, whoselead singer Scott Hutchison died in May, will play at Kelvingrove Park in Glasgow.Eddi Reader will headline Aberdeenrsquos show in the Duthie Park, whileKyle Falconer will top the bill in Dundeersquos Slessor Gardens.The event ends on Sunday at am.Josh Littlejohn, co-founder of organiser Social Bite, said: ldquoWe were completely blown away by the thousands of people who joined this movement and supported Sleep in the Park last year.ldquoWe want to build on this across the whole of Scotland.

title: line-of-duty-star-compston-i-never-thought-id-star-in-primetime-show
story: The actor, who plays Detective Sergeant Steve Arnott, said he did not think he was someone ldquoMiddle England would respond to as he was quizzed about his career alongside the showrsquos creator, Jed Mercurio, in Glasgow.The pair, currentlyfilming the fth series of the police drama in Belfast, spoke to students studying TV fiction writing at Glasgow Caledonian University.We had a great time fanastic to see the enthusiasm of students past and present, be back soon! https:t.co ODfkOeRRSmdash martin compstonDecember , Compston said he was grateful to Mercurio for his role in the hit show, and to film director Ken Loach, who put him on screen for the first time in rsquos Sweet Sixteen.The Scottish actor said:ldquoI owe my whole career to Ken Loach, who took a chance on me, and Jed, who put me in front of a wide audience.ldquoI never thought Irsquod be cast as a lead in a primetime BBC show, I just never thought Irsquod be someone Middle England would respond to.ldquoFor every great job Irsquove had, Irsquove had at least  or  rejections, so yoursquove got to be thick-skinned and yoursquove got to enjoy it.Speaking about filming Line Of Dutyrsquosinterrogation scenes, he said:ldquoThey are like mini one-act plays, you earn your money that day.ldquoWhen the scripts come out the fear is there, and Irsquom hoping Irsquom not in one, but when yoursquore not in it, you wish you were. The last one we were doing was - pages ndash yoursquore talking -minute takes.Mercurio recalled his shock on hearing Compston dropping the English accent he uses in the show for the first time, off the set.ldquoOnly two things make him break the accent ndash drink and Celtic when hersquos shouting at the TV.ldquoThe first time I heard Martin speak in his natural accent was when he was drunk. We had probably known each for three or four months at that point.Mercurio also created Bodyguard, the biggest BBC drama for a decade when it aired earlier this year, starringRichard Madden and Keeley Hawes.He told students:ldquoBodyguard came from the fact Line Of Duty was on BBC Two.ldquoThe drama budgets are much smaller on BBC Two and they tend to not be that interested in ing series.ldquoI was asked to do Bodyguard as a BBC One thriller to take the place of Line Of Dutyit didnrsquot get recommissioned, but itrsquos ended up being the best of both worlds, as Line Of Duty moved across.

title: china-launches-pioneering-mission-to-far-side-of-moon
story: A Long March B rocket carrying a lunar probe blasted off at .am local time from the Xichang Satellite Launch Centre in Sichuan Province in south-western China, the official Xinhua News Agency said.With its Changrsquoe  mission, China hopes to be the first country to make a soft landing, which is a landing of a spacecraft during which no serious damage is incurred.The moonrsquos far side is also known as the dark side because it faces away from Earth and remains comparatively unknown.It has a dferent composition than sites on the near side, where previous missions have landed.If successful, the mission would propel the Chinese space programme to a leading position in one of the most important areas of lunar exploration.China landed its Yutu, or Jade Rabbit, rover on the moon five years ago and plans to send its Changrsquoe  probe there next year and have itto Earth with samples ndash the first time that will have been done since .A crewed lunar mission is also under consideration.Changrsquoe  is also a lander-rover combination and will explore both above and below the lunar surface after arriving at the South Pole-Aitken basinrsquos Von Karman crater following a -day journey.It will also perform radio-astronomical studies that, because the far side always faces away from Earth, will be ldquofree from interference from our planetrsquos ionosphere, human-made radio frequencies and auroral radiation noise, space industry expert Leonard David wrote on the website Space.It may also carry plant seeds and silkworm eggs, according to Xinhua.Changrsquoe is the goddess of the moon in Chinese mythology.China conducted its first crewed space mission in , making it only the third country after Russia and the US to do so.It has put two space stations into orbit, one of which is still operating as a precursor to a more than -ton station that is due to come online in .The launch of a Mars rover is planned for the mid-s.To facilitate communication between controllers on Earth and the Changrsquoe  mission, China in May launched a relay satellite named Queqiao, or Magpie Bridge, after an ancient Chinese folk tale.Chinarsquos space programme has benefited from co-operation with Russia and European nations, although it was excluded from the -ton International Space Station, mainly due to US legislation barring such co-operation amid concerns over its strong military connections.Its programme also suffered a rare setback last year with the failed launch of its Long March  rocket.

title: nasa-lander-captures-first-sounds-of-martian-wind
story: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory released audio clips of the alien wind, which is estimated to be blowing between mph to mph.The low-frequency rumblings were collected by the InSight lander during its first week of operations on Mars.These are the first sounds from Mars that are detectable by human ears, according to the researchers.ldquoReminds me of sitting outside on a windy summer afternoon hellip In some sense, this is what it would sound likeyou were sitting on the InSight lander on Mars, Cornell Universityrsquos Don Banfield told reporters.LIVE NOW: The Mars InSight lander has been sending us good vibrations! Tune in to hear the landerrsquos recordings of wind vibrations on the red planet, as well as what our scientists think about the #SoundsOfMars! https:t.co kGKjoqgeV pic hYGcnvxxaCmdash NASADecember , Scientists involved in the project agree the sound has an otherworldly quality to it.Thomas Pike, of Imperial College London, said the rumbling is ldquorather dferent to anything that wersquove experienced on Earth, and I think it just gives us another way of thinking about how far away we are getting these signals.The noise is of the wind blowing against InSightrsquos solar  and the resulting vibration of the entire spacecraft.The sounds were recorded by an air pressure sensor inside the lander that is part of a weather station, as well as the seismometer on the deck of the spacecraft.The low frequencies are a result of Marsrsquo thin air density and even more so the seismometer itself ndash it is meant to detect underground seismic waves, well below the threshold of human hearing.The seismometer will be moved to the Martian surface in the coming weeks until then, the team plans to record more wind noise.The  Viking landers on Mars picked up spacecraft shaking caused by wind, but it would be a stretch to consider it sound, said InSightrsquos lead scientist Bruce Banerdt, of JPL in Pasadena, Calornia.InSight landed on Mars on November .ldquoWersquore all still on a high from the landing last week hellip and here we are less than two weeks after landing, and wersquove already got some amazing new science, said Nasarsquos Lori Glaze, acting director of planetary science.ldquoItrsquos cool, itrsquos fun.

title: amber-rudd-says-norway-style-brexit-a-plausible-alternative-if-mays-deal-rejected

title: kemnay post office set to reopen in 2019
story: The Kemnay Post Office is set to reopen next month in a new location.The Post Office has announced that the new community branch will be located at the McColl’s shop on Aquithie Road.The new location is just a short walk from the previous Post Office on High Street, which has been temporarily closed since October due to the resignation of the previous Postmaster and the withdrawal of the premises for Post Office use.When the move goes ahead, the branch will open, from am–pm Monday to Saturday and am–pm on Sunday. Adam Williams, Post Office Commercial Partnership Executive said: “We are making it easier for customers to get their cash, send and collect their mail and do their banking because we know how important these services are to local residents.“We are confident that this vibrant new-style Post Office at the heart of the local community will meet customer needs.” Although the decision has been made to reopen the branch Post Office welcomes feedback on any issues customers would like considered.Post Office will be accepting comments until  January .Customers can share their views during the consultation online at postofficeviews with the branch code .Submissions can also be made via email to comments@postoffice, by post to Freepost YOUR COMMENTS, or by telephone     or Textphone    .Local MP Andrew Bowie commented: “I very much welcome the news a new home has been found for the Post Office in Kemnay.“I said at the time of the initial announcement that it sounded very much like a temporary measure.“I am sure local residents will be very pleased to hear that they will be able to use the McColl shop in future.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: loco works lunch secures a grand slam
story: Inverurie Loco Works Football Club#s ninth annual Business Lunch was held at The Marclfe on Friday, November .The event, sponsored by CALA Homes, celebrated another successful year and guest speaker, Sue Barker, inspired attendees with stories of her tennis career and le as a television presenter.The British sports personality, who was secured as this year’s star speaker by the Scottish Highland Football Leagueclub, addressed more than  guests at the prestigious fundraising event, which is now recognised as a must-attend event among business people across Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire.CALA Homes, the UK’s most upmarket major homebuilder, came on board once again as the headline sponsor for the  event while Sue’s successful stint on the stage helped secure the business lunch’s reputation as the most prestigious businessin the region.Delivering a question and answer session for guests, Sue was probed about her sports and television career, and her experience fronting the corporation’s coverage of Wimbledon and A Question of Sport.Comedian Bill Copeland entertained guests.Mike Naysmith, Managing Director at CALA Homes, said: “We were delighted to support the Loco Works Business Lunch in its ninth year and thoroughly enjoyed the event as guests as well as the headline sponsor.“Momentum for the Loco’s lunch is building year-on-year – particularly with the calibre of inspirational guests attending the event.“We’ve supported the club for a number of years, as well as Garioch Sports Club in Inverurie, and it’s a pleasure to continue our close links with the town.”Vice Chairman and event organiser, Graeme Hay, said: “We are overwhelmed with the success of the lunch and would like to thank all who attended for making it another fantastic year. We are already looking forward to and planning next year’s event which at this very early stage is now completely sold out.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Two for court after Kemnay drug recovery viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: parlour celebrates one year anniversary
story: A whopping , litres of ice cream # the equivalent of . million licks or , bathtubs # have been consumed in the first year of a much-loved brand opening its first parlour.Things are looking sweet for Mackie’s of Scotland’s . parlour since it opened its doors back in December last year, with , orders meaning it has now served enough for almost every person in Aberdeen.Sales have steadily increased over the twelve months, with a summer of record-breaking hours of sunshine seeing them reach their highest levels in August.Karin Hayhow, Marketing Director at Mackie’s, said: “. has been our first retail venture, and after all the hard work that has gone into opening and running it it’s so pleasing to see our vision come together.“We’re really enjoying working on this new side of our business as it allows us to be creative with our ice cream and desserts – and it’s a great way for us to test new products and get instant feedback from customers.“We love the idea of one day expanding this arm of Mackie’s - it’s an exciting thought to consider for the future.”The best-selling scoop at . has been its Honeycomb flavour, which it makes by hand on its Westertown farm, shortly followed by its Traditional, Salted Caramel and Triple Chocolate flavours.. offers over , flavour combinations, though, thanks in no small part to its north east location, its Buttery  Jam ice cream has performed well too.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at ., said: “We’ve had some memorable moments at the parlour, from the introduction of the peanut butter tap to our haggis ice cream.“The team here are fantastic to work with - they all get behind our crazy ideas and help bring them to le.”While ice cream has certainly scooped up the biggest portion of sales, the parlour’s waffles have been a surprisingly big hit and the parlour has had to buy two more waffle machines for its kitchen as a result.As well as a wide range of ice cream, . serves coffee from local roasters Caber Coffee and features two centrepiece chocolate taps – one white and one milk - delivering Mackie’s own highest quality melted chocolate on demand for serving over its desserts.Named ., the parlour is located exactly . miles from the Mackie’s Westertown family farm, where it produces its renowned ice cream and chocolate ranges.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Eileen Donald, Eric Massey, Nan Hosie, Graham and Alistair from Inverurie Mens Shed, Jim McColl and Kathleen Downie in Hanover Courts garden"  Garden makeover for Inverurie’s Hanover Court viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: scottish charity africa on the ball needs our readers support
story: Creating the best community sports club in the world is the goal of Scottish charity Africa on the Ball.And it is hoping to enlist our readers’ help to make sure it nets that ambition.Scoring is nothing new to striker Jimmy Bone, who is a legend in Scottish football. But as a coach, he also helped a Zambian team to great success. So he was more than happy to become a patron of Africa on the Ball.The charity launched its own supporters’ club last month in the hopes of signing up more Scots.With just over  people already championing the club, the co-founders hope to grow that to at least .Africa on the Ball formed Kalingalinga On The Ball FC in Zambia in .Its mission was to provide access to schools, employment opportunities and healthcare education by supporting and growing grassroots football, initially in Kalingalinga near Lusaka.Fellow founder...Elena Sarra was working at Stirling Univeristy when Andrew approached her for advice. Having worked in Cameroon with Vision Aid, she was more than happy to help him set up Africa on the Ball and is now one of several trustees.With the help of two paid coaches, Kelvin Chasauka and Gracious Chipilauka, it has grown from a community venture to a fourth-tier club.It has also developed food and community litter picking programmes and an educational scholarship fund for players to finish their basic schooling.In , the boys and girls who play in the teams help with Africa on the Ball’s outreach programme, undertaking educational and football-focused sessions in deprived communities, as well as at the local orphanage and primary schools.In Zambia, the average le expectancy is under  years old so football is used to deliver vital education and health programmes.Andrew Jenkin, founding trustee of Africa on the Ball, said: “Our aspiration is to be the best community sports club in the world, using the unique ability of football to advance education, healthcare and enterprise and positively change lives. “Although we’re a relatively small charity, we hope the Supporters’ Club will help drastically grow our reach throughout the continent while offering donors a uinque, engaging experience with our work”.It was while studying journalism at Stirling University that Essex-born Andrew hit on the idea for Africa on the Ball.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.thesouthernreporter webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Meeting guests...pictured at the last meeting of Borders Older Peoples Forum areCouncillor Claire Ramage, speaker Dr Vikki McCall and chairwoman Diana Findley."   Councillor Claire Ramage, speaker Dr Vikki McCall and chairwoman Diana Findley."
